title: Suppose creativity was not a sign of intelligence but instead a sign of how good you are at getting ...

attachments.displayName:
Suppose creativity was not a sign of intelligence but instead a sign of how good you are at getting around your limited [mental] resources.

Consider this example. I ask you what is 1 + 2 + 3. Six, you say immediately. I ask another person whose memory is much, much worse than yours - it'd take them forever to do it manually. To get around that they spend a bit more time time on the problem to invent a trick. More than you but less than it would have taken them to manually add [1..3]. A side effect of their trick is it works in general for any question of that format and costs much less effort than you spend. But you're not impressed cause you can add the numbers without even thinking.

Now I ask you. What is 1 + 2 + 3 + ... + 1000. You know a formula and quickly answer. The formula is clever and only a few people can come up with it from scratch.  Another person who doesn't know the formula not only answers but does so even more quickly. Because their mind works really fast they can add up all the numbers without trying. But you are not impressed because it's 'just brute force' (although you would be impressed if they were human: http://mathworld.wolfram.com/TwoTrainsPuzzle.html).

There are a few morals to this story. The first is, not to use our limitations to judge other minds, less or greater. But it goes both ways, we can't expect to ever recognize creativity in computers, in fact it might even be the case that a mind as fast as that never has need for creativity and certainly not ever recognizably so.
=========================================================

A corollary to this (or at least very related) is the importance of learning to program no matter the skill level you reach. If you give a room full of kids, all with easily programmable devices and ask them to sum up 1 to 100, they no longer all need to be geniuses to answer in comparable time. Now you no longer need to be Gauss (genius) or von Neumann (speed) to trivially solve the Two Trains puzzle.

But the new Büttner just might ask his pupils to write a program to calculate the sum of any arithmetic progression. A new Gauss, with the same keen insight, could create a very efficient program based on the pairing idea—and that feat still deserves the highest admiration. But the modern Gauss might not be the first to fling his or her laptop on the table and cry "There it lies!" Writing that clever program—and testing and debugging it, and proving its correctness—would be no quicker than writing the straightforward step-by-step version. In this respect, technology may be something of an equalizer.

http://www.americanscientist.org/issues/id.3483,y.0,no.,content.true,page.5,css.print/issue.aspx
